A lot of reviews harp on about the disappointing single player, but I think this misses the point - it's just your standard tacked on single player in a game that's designed from the ground up to be played online. The game's fault lies in bringing in a story that no one playing the game cares about, and making it seem relevant. Really, they should have ditched the idea of a storylined campaign completely, because their execution doesn't make any sense *anyway*.

If you're not familiar with Enemy Territory or objective based multiplayer, then you have to approach Brink without preconceptions. This probably isn't like any game you've played before. Depending on your role,  playing well might mean avoiding combat altogether. The focus is always on the objective, whether it's a door that needs hacking/defending, a prisoner that needs escorting/stopping. Kills and deaths don't matter if they're not in service of the team.

If you are familiar with those games, then Brink ... is a lighter, faster, rougher, yes, but much more accessible iteration of the genre. Just don't come in expecting Halo or CoD.

I don't want to prematurely go into a rant about the Joystiq review, because I've only played it a few hours myself. I'll give more elaborate impressions as I play more, but as of right now, a 2 out of 5 seems incredibly harsh for an incredibly competent game that might just not be everyone's cup of tea.
The part of me that enjoys Battlefield *might* enjoy this.

Regarding the lag that the Ars Technica review mentions, that was definitely my experience for the first hour or so. I don't know what it was, some sort of server overload, beats me. But all the games I played after were lag free, and fun!
8/10 from Eurogamer, http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-05-10-brink-review
It's no ETQW. It's sort of like Enemy Territory-lite. There's a lot that's weird, not least of all the fact that simply getting into a multiplayer game with friends seems like some sort of puzzle.
